title: brunton-theatre-groups-heading-online
story: In March, , all youth and adult theatre groups were postponed due to the Covid- pandemic, and they went online.A spokesperson for the Musselburgh-based Brunton Theatre said: ldquoLike many other art forms, the classes went online, providing an opportunity for fun, interaction and creativity ndash a fantastic tonic to trying times.Thanks to funding The Brunton Theatre Trust secured through Creative Scotland, the youth theatre network and Brunton Players are able to continue online programmes this year, with classes being offered for a low fee.The sessions will recommence online from Monday, February  and run for eight weeks, continuing through the February school break.All classes are led by experienced and qualied drama professionals.This term, some of the ELYT groups will be working with Wonder Fools, a charity and theatre company, on its lsquoPositive Stories For Negative Timesrsquo project.Wonder Fools has commissioned five plays by UK writers, which have been made available online for community theatre, charity and youth groups to perform.The company also provides a framework about how to rehearse, direct and record the works. The final performances will be filmed and uploaded to the internet, alongside all other performances made as part of this project, where they will be free to view.The Brunton spokesperson said feedback for the online youth theatre classes has been very positive.Brunton Players is a community theatre group for adults and usually meets weekly at The Brunton, with performances on stage at the Musselburgh venue.Now, participants are enjoying being creative together and practising performance skills online, with weekly workshops.The spokesperson added: ldquoThis is a great way to combat isolation and use creativity to have fun. New members are very welcome no previous experience is required.More information is available at www.thebrunton or contact youththeatre@eastlothian.gov.uk

title: driver-slammed-touring-north-coast-500-lockdown
story: Adam Jarguz posted on a social media site for owners of the Seat Leon MK car that he had made the three-day road trip last week.Alongside pictures he had taken on his journey was a caption that read ldquoNC complete.He added that he camped on the route, as hotels and BBs were closed, and did not encounter anyone during the trip, using pay-at-pump services for fuel.Under current Scottish Government lockdown restrictions, it is against the law to leave your home for anything other than an essential reason, with people urged to avoid unnecessary travel.Mr Jarguz has been criticised by members of the public who live along the route and by the North Coast  Ltd company.Tom Campbell, executive chairman of North Coast  Ltd, said: ldquoWe strongly condemn any irresponsible or anti-social behaviour conducted by a minority of visitors on the NC and would urge people always to report such behaviour to Police Scotland and other relevant authorities in the first instance.Margaret Meek, co-founder of NC The Land Weeps social media page, said: ldquoItrsquos not a grey area:itrsquos illegal to go from East Lothianto the Highlands for a jaunt for non-essential travel.ldquoObviously he did not drive  miles on a round trip and not get out of his car. Itrsquos not rocket science.Ali Gillespie, from Inverness, who spotted the social media post, said: ldquoYou only need to look at whatrsquos happening in Barra to see what happens when Covid arrives in wee places where locals arenrsquot expecting it.ldquoSelfish in the extreme.Mr Jarguz could not be reached for comment.

title: cameron-susan-law-say-goodbye-gullanes-mallard-hotel
story: The Mallard, on the villagersquos East Links Road, has been owned and managed by husband-and-we Susan and Cameron Law since .It was previously owned by Susanrsquos parents, Iain and Flora Clark, who took the business over in , after running a restaurant in Pitlochry.Iain chose the hotelrsquos name after being inspired by the wildle in Aberlady Bay.Sadly, he died four years later but Flora, Susan and the rest of the family worked together to keep the business going.When Flora died in , Susan and Cameron took over The Mallard.Susan said: ldquoHotel le is quite challenging sometimes, but wersquove met lots and lots of great people over the years.ldquoIt is quite sad in these Covid times people have had to give up businesses for financial reasons but we are really lucky that that was not the case for us.ldquoMy dad always used to say lsquohospitality with informalityrsquo, which is what we strove to achieve. We will miss hotel le.The pair had always planned to retire at this time but hopes for a large party have been scuppered due to the pandemic.As well as enjoying time with family, friends, and a new grandchild who was born in December, Susan and Cameron will be kept busy by their many hobbies and interests.Susan is former chairman and current service co-ordinator at Muirfield Riding Therapy, receiving an MBE for her work there and Cameron is a member at North Berwick Golf Club. They also plan to travel, when lockdown restrictions allow.But first on the to-do list is househunting. Susan has lived on the hotelrsquos premises since her parents owned it, with Cameron moving in after their marriage in .The pair, who previously ran The Ugly Duckling cafe in the village, will not be moving far and plan to stay in East Lothian, a community they have grown to love.Susan called the ending ldquobittersweet, adding that ldquoit is really hard to pick out just one memory from the past -and-a-half years of her family running The Mallard.She said she would rather pay tribute to and thank all the customers, guests and staff who had been a huge part of their lives. She added: ldquoWe have not been able to say proper goodbyes to people, which is quite sad.ldquoSome of them have been coming to the hotel for over  years.ldquoIrsquove said to the new owners that I want to meet up with some of the guests and say goodbye properly.ldquoAmong the plans was a two-day open-door party to allow people to drop in and say farewell.ldquoWorking in a hotel is an all-consuming business so retirement will take some getting used to. I donrsquot want to become a couch potato though! I donrsquot feel old enough to retire at all.: Ambitious plans for village hotelPlans last year by Structured House Group to demolish and replace the hotel with a new -bedroomed version will not go ahead.The Mallard has now been sold to East Lothian-based company Watchman Inns the hotelrsquos name is being changed to The Watchman and it is currently undergoing a refurbishment, with hopes it will reopen in July.Susan said that, with the name change, it was like she was ldquotaking [The Mallard name] with them, adding that it would be ldquoin our hearts and memories.The lettering that spells out the hotelrsquos name on the front of the building have also been gted to Susan and Cameron.

title: east-lothian-councils-carbon-footprint-reduction-continues
story: The figures, released in a report earlier this month, show the local authority maintained its carbon footprint reduction from   to  , with a . per cent drop from , tCOeto , tCOe.Councillor Norman Hampshire, environment spokesperson, said: ldquoIn our Climate Change Strategy ndash, which was approved in January , the council set out its commitment to continue to reduce emissions towards reaching net zero and to continue to improve the integrity of our emissions data and reporting mechanisms.The report noted that the latest figures continue the trend for a ldquosignicant and steady overall reduction in the councilrsquos corporate emissions since a baseline measurement in  . This year, the council stated, further improvements were made to a system for recording the emissions from its vehicle fleet to further improve accuracy.Mr Hampshire added: ldquoEast Lothian is a rapidly growing area itrsquos extremely encouraging that we are continuing to make good progress in our total emissions reduction year on year in the context of signicant population growth.ldquoWe continue to focus on specic considerations around developments within the councilrsquos estate and aim to ensure appropriate energy efficient infrastructure and technology is utilised as appropriate.ldquoFollowing the enactment of the Climate Change Act  public bodies across the country are expected to lead by example in tackling climate change and contributing towards achieving the ambitious net zero emissions target.Mr Hampshire said: ldquoThe council is a provider of services, a major employer and a procurer of goods and services across the county and just last month saw the adoption of a new sustainable procurement policy.ldquoThe work of the council this year has been greatly impacted by Covid- but any longer term effects the pandemic has had on the councilrsquos energy use, fleet mileage and corporate emissions will not be detailed until next yearrsquos annual report, which will cover the financial year  .The full report, lsquoEast Lothian Councilrsquos Public Sector Climate Change Reporting  rsquo, can be viewed at eastlothian.gov.uk meetings meeting  members_library_service

title: grand-designs-experiment-north-berwick-high-street-refused
story: Architect Robin Sutherland came up with the Passivhaus build for his family after they bought property at  High Street, North Berwick.With the front of the property refurbished into a new shop front with offices for the architect upstairs , he turned his attention to designing a family home on the strip of land behind it, which measures . metres long and . metres wide.Plans showed the ground floor having a bathroom and study bedroom, with parking bays at the front and a courtyard garden at the rear a bedroom, kitchen diner and outside roof terrace on the first floor and, on the second floor, a living room and bedroom.However, despite his design being described by one councillor as ldquoextraordinary, his vision for his new home clashed with neighbours, the community council and ward councillors, who claimed it went against the arearsquos conservation status.And despite planning officers ruling that the proposed house met its policies, the planning committee refused planning permission by six votes to five.Mr Sutherlandrsquos proposed home would have had room widths of . metres.In his design statement to planners, he said: ldquoThe site is very narrow, with a width of approximately . metres however, an internal room width of .m is achievable, which is comfortably within the bounds of normally scaled domestic space.But Councillor Jane Henderson, ward member, told the committee that the width of the home would be ldquonot much wider than a shipping container, my goodness gracious.She said: ldquoI am not convinced this is the best place for a Grand Designs experiment, adding: ldquoJust because theoretically it can be done does not make it right.Grand Designs is a popular and long-running home improvements TV show where unique and daringly designed homes are built.Neighbours overlooking the proposed house had objections about the impact of the three-storey home on their privacy, in particular a proposed roof terrace. And they raised concerns about the use of zinccladding on the walls and roo.Mr Sutherland highlighted other properties in North Berwick which had zinc cladding Councillor Jim Goodfellow, ward member, described the proposed new house as a ldquozinc house.North Berwick Community Council also lodged objections, citing the impact of the zinc materials on the conservation area and on neighboursrsquo privacy and amenity.Councillor Norman Hampshire, planning convenor, backed the proposals, highlighting that planning officers had ruled the design met the councilrsquos relevant planning policies.He said the house was something which would, in time, be viewed as an ldquoattractive addition to the townrsquos conservation area.FAREWELL: Hotel owners check out after familys near  years in businessHowever, Councillor Willie Innes, council leader, pointed to the strength of concerns from the community and said that while he appreciated the ldquoextraordinary way the architect had created the design for the house, it was in the wrong location.He said: ldquoI accept what local members are saying. I think the overall impact would be too signicant.The committee voted by six members to five to refuse planning permission.Mr Sutherland declined to comment following the decision.

title: iain-gray-msp-independence-route-map-beggars-belief
story: However, the reality is very dferent, with work ongoing on numerous important pieces of legislation.One of these was the Protection of Workers Bill, which passed its final stage last week. It introduces a new statutory offence of assaulting, threatening or abusing a retail worker and provides further legal protections when the worker is carrying out their statutory duties, such as age restricted sales.Another Bill that passed its first stage last week, and which I was pleased to speak in support of, was the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child Bill. This legislation will directly incorporate the UNCRC into Scottish law and make it unlawful for public authorities to act incompatibly with the UNCRC requirements.There is a local link to this work, too, thanks to StreetsAhead Tranent.This project saw children from the Ross High School cluster visit Geneva to share their work directly with the UN Committee on the Rights of the Child, and other children and adults from around the world.On a less positive note, the Culpable Homicide Bill fell last week after SNP MSPs failed to support it.It sought to ensure suitable convictions would take place in the event of a workplace death, where recklessness or gross negligence of iniduals, companies or organisations could be proven. It is a missed opportunity to act and help save lives at work.One political development we could do without is the SNP governmentrsquos new -point route map to independence.It really does beggar belief that even in the middle of the pandemic they continue to make breaking up the UK their top priority.It seems clear that its focus must be on recovering from the pandemic and uniting the country.

title: dementia-friendly-east-lothian-organise-free-virtual-concert-scottish-singer
story: Bruce Davies, who has been a full-time professional entertainer since , will be undertaking the virtual performance, called lsquoCelebrating Scotlandrsquo, on Thursday .Dementia Friendly East Lothian has organised the event and it begins at .pm the group aims to make communities in East Lothian more welcoming and le better for those living with dementia.Brucersquos musical celebration is being held both on Facebook Live and on Zoom.For those wishing to watch via Zoom are asked to email Maya@dfel.org.uk for the link.Those at Dementia Friendly East Lothian say that while haggis is optional, singing and wearing tartan are encouraged.For more information visit Dementia Friendly East Lothianrsquos Facebook page or the event page.Bruce is currently the singing host in Edinburghrsquos lsquoSpirit of Scotland Showrsquo, he has also performed at the Edinburgh Fringe and Folk Festivals as well as ious parts of America. title: steeplejacks-tackle-maintenance-st-michaels-church
story: The specialist team completed an inspection of the lightning conductors and steeple, removed vegetation and also carried out work on an opening where coverings had fallen inwards.The project was undertaken by Northern Steeplejacks, which is based at Newtongrange in Midlothian.The cockerel weathervane was refurbished under a previous contract.There has been a church on the site since the th century.The present church was built in  to the design of Robert Nisbet and the steeple is recorded as being by the architect William Sibbald, following his earlier design for that at St Andrewrsquos, George Street, Edinburgh, in .This project was to a large extent the brainchild of the illustrious minister of St Michaelrsquos, Dr Alexander lsquoJupiterrsquo Carlyle.The kirk stands on the site of a Roman praetorium and replaces a medieval church. It has an Adam-style ceiling and stained glass.The building was substantially altered to accommodate the innovative new trend in worship ndash a pipe organ ndash in . This Lewis organ was quite radical in its design at that time.St Michaelrsquos boasts some notable ministers in its post-Reformation history, such as the second minister, The Rev Andrew Blackhall, who was an accomplished composer of music.The Rev Alexander Carlyle was a pioneer of the Sunday School movement and his autobiography shed light on a turbulent period in Scotlandrsquos history.The Rev John Beveridge was a campaigner for the renewal of worship and distinguished himself by his devotion to duty during a cholera outbreak.In , St Michaelrsquos celebrated the th anniversary of the present building, which is listed lsquoCategory Arsquo, meaning it is of special architectural or historical interest and is an outstanding example of a particular period, style or building type.

title: weekend-coronavirus-vaccine-clinic-set-riverside-medical-practice
story: They will be invited to attend on Saturday to receive their jabs from GP partner Dr Catherine Cameron, nurses Diane Fyffe, Delia Marriott, Sarah Falconer and Gillian Fulton, and general practice paramedic Tracy Henry.Almost  per cent of the first priority group have been vaccinated already and, while Riverside and other GP practices across the country are still constrained by vaccine supply, the third vaccine allocation sent to Riverside was large enough to warrant a weekend clinic.Staff will soon start to vaccinate people aged - and those in the shielding group who are defined on medical grounds as extremely vulnerable from Covid-.The practice, based at Musselburgh Primary Care Centre, is the largest in East Lothian and one of the biggest in Scotland, with about , patients.Dr Joanna Stenke, GP partner, said: ldquoOur dedicated team are delighted to be coming into the practice at the weekend to get as many of the first priority group vaccinated as possible.ldquoGPs across Scotland were asked by the Scottish Government to vaccinate registered patients aged  and over who can attend the clinic in person and wersquore pleased to have been able to vaccinate  of this group already at Riverside. Most people have been delighted when wersquove phoned to offer an appointment, and we really enjoy making the call.She added: ldquoThis weekend clinic will see the majority of our remaining patients aged  and over vaccinated, with the remaining few to be vaccinated when we receive our next vaccine allocation.ldquoWersquoll then begin to offer vaccine appointments to registered patients aged - who can attend the clinic in person along with shielders of all ages. Shielders are defined as those who have already received a shielders letter from the government or their GP.Eligible patients will be contacted by phone by the team at Riverside. Patients should wait to be contacted to help the team get the vaccines out to patients as soon as possible.The next priority group, those aged - years, will also start to be vaccinated shortly - but this is currently planned to take place in mass vaccination venues and health board clinics rather than in GP surgeries.Queen Margaret University has been named as a mass vaccination venue.Local health board teams will vaccinate housebound registered patients and these patients should wait to be contacted by them direct.For more information about the vaccination programme at Riverside, including which vaccine is being used and a weekly update on numbers vaccinated, visit www.theriversidepractice covid--vaccination-underway-at-riversidePatients are being advised to continue to follow local and national restrictions after receiving the vaccine.A spokesperson for the East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnership said: ldquoI can say that the vaccination programme in East Lothian is progressing well, in line with the planned national roll-out.But East Lothian MSP Iain Gray has described the speed of the Covid- vaccine rollout in East Lothian as a whole as ldquounacceptable.: Speed of Covid vaccine rollout labelled lsquounacceptablersquoThe latest figures show that , people had been vaccinated across the county up to Sunday, January  ndash . per cent of the countyrsquos population. This placed East Lothian as the third slowest council area in Scotland for vaccines being administered.John Swinney MSP, Deputy First Minister, insisted this week that the national vaccination programme was on track.He said: ldquoGood progress has been made on the delivery of the vaccine for over-s. We have got to  per cent of care home residents, who are most at risk of morbidity from Covid.ldquoWe are in a majority now in over-s and that task will be completed by the end of the first week in February.

title: stuart-rollo-wins-porsche-macan-gts-70-000-botb-competition
story: Competition winner Stuart Rollo, of Prestonpans, received the surprise of a letime when he was told he would be taking home a Porsche Macan GTS, worth about pound,.But his day got even better when he was then informed that pound, would be coming his way too.His online ticket cost just pound.The -year-old was celebrating after receiving a video call from Virgin Radio UK presenter Christian Williams that he had won the prizes in BOTBrsquos long-running Dream Car Competition.Stuart said: ldquoThis is crazy. title: bogus-john-knoxs-house-haddington
story: According to a paper by the local historian J.H. Jamieson, in the third volume of the East Lothian Antiquarian and Field Naturalistsrsquo Society, the house on the eastern side of the Gfordgate pointed out as Knoxrsquos birthplace was demolished prior to .In , none less than celebrated essayist and historian Thomas Carlyle made sure that an oak was planted and a memorial stone erected on the site this oak still remains today and is quite a majestic tree.It is a mysterious matter that there was a lsquoJohn Knoxrsquos Housersquo in Haddington in Edwardian times, the subject of several picture postcards, including one by the notable North Berwick artist Reginald Phillimore.The truth appears to be, according to the Jamieson article, that another house, situated on the western side of the Gfordgate, was pointed out to the tourists as the birthplace of John Knox, although it only dated back to the th century.The mischievous locals received generous tips from the gullible tourists, who had come from Edinburgh and beyond to see the great Reformerrsquos birthplace.A rustic-looking building, this bogus lsquoKnoxrsquos Housersquo, was still standing as recently as the s, but it does not remain today.It is curious that Knoxrsquos birthplace is not definitely known, with some historians advocating the villages of Gford or Morham the house in Edinburgh pointed out as lsquoJohn Knoxrsquos Housersquo was never inhabited by the Reformer, but was named from an obscure popular tradition arising in the early th century nor is the exact site of Knoxrsquos grave known, although a plaque is said to mark it in what is today the car park in Parliament Square.

title: gardening-column-succulents-cacti
story: In this column wersquore looking at succulents and cacti ndash a group of indoor plants that are so easy that theyrsquoreimpossible to get wrong.Succulents and cacti tend to be grouped together because they can store water in their tissues that enables them to survive hot, dry conditions. This adaptation means that they are ideally suited to being houseplants, particularly in homes where the owners are forgetful waterers!Succulent is a general description for plants that have tissues adapted to store water but doesnrsquot refer to a specic plant. On the other hand, cactus is a botanical name for plants belonging to the plant family Cactaceae and, for specic physiological reasons, may not always be regarded as succulents.Succulent suggestionsAmongst the toughest, most robust indoor succulents is the sanseveria, a wide range of plants whose common names include mother-in-lawrsquos tongue , snake plantand birds nest plant .With bold, thick, simple leaves, theyrsquore almost sculptural in appearance, tolerant of low light levels and, because they require minimal attention, theyrsquore an obvious choice for those with little or no experience of houseplants.Sanseveria are particularly good at improving the indoor air quality theyrsquore known to remove air pollutants including formaldehyde, xylene and toluene and, because they convert carbon dioxide to oxygen at night, theyrsquore popular bedroom plants.Another group of plants that are particularly easy to care for are the aloes, which the ancient Egyptians called lsquoimmortality plantsrsquo because they are almost indestructible.The natural healing benefits of aloe vera has made it popular for centuries and is iously credited with the ability to soothe irritated or burned skin, improve skin, hair, oral hygiene and digestion and to treat acne and arthritis.Like sanseveria, aloe requires very little care, tolerates low light levels and infrequent watering, removes air-borne pollutants and oxygenates the air at night, which aids sleep.One of our favourite succulents is the echiveria, which grows in compact rosettes of succulent, sometimes coloured leaves from which flowering stalks may grow.These plants like a reasonable amount of light, some dilute feed when actively growing and prefer under-watering to over-watering. A happy echiveria will produce little plantlets which can be removed and grown into new plants.Carefree cactusIt would be impossible to talk about easy-to-care for plants without mentioning cacti, which have well-developed survival adaptations.Most cacti have developed spines which in fact are highly modied leaves. Not only do these spines help prevent the plant being grazed, but they also reduce the airflow around the plant, which helps it conserve water.Photosynthesis takes place on the stemand its shallow, far-reaching root system enables the cactus to react quickly and absorb any water reaching the ground.Whilst the enormous tree-like cacti of the American desert may be the first cactus that springs to mind, wersquove highlighted some interesting houseplant types below that are incredibly easy to look after and certainly wonrsquot take over your home!There are many dferent shapes of cacti, including round, flat, columnar, smooth, bumpy, ribbed and fluted, and itrsquos important to note that some of these actually change shape depending on how much water is stored in the stem at the time!Not all cacti have fully developed spines. For example, the popular schlumbergera, of which the best-known culti is the Christmas-flowering cactus, has less modied leaves which look like lsquoteethrsquo along the edge of their stems. Their stems grow in lsquosegmentsrsquo and resemble flattened pads, with their flowers being produced at the end of the segments.Although the Christmas-flowering culti is most popular in the UK, there are dferent cultis which flower at dferent times of the year.In their natural habitat, schlumbergera grow on trees or in rocks and generally enjoy shady habitats with high humidity, making them an ideal choice for bathrooms.If yoursquore looking for an unusual and interesting but easy-to-care-for indoor hanging plant, you might consider the aporocactus ndash a group of tree-growing cactus that grow well in a hanging pot.For a cactus with impact, the gymnocalycium mihanovichii is a sure winner. The top part of the stem on this cactus lacks green pigmentand can be bright red, yellow or other amazing colours.So,yoursquore looking for a plant that thrives on neglect, hopefully wersquove given you some ideas!Just remember that the golden rule for cacti and succulents is to under-water rather than over-water ndash too much moisture will cause disease and rot.For more information, take a look on our website at www.merryhatton

title: mary-contini-column-food-thought-covid
story: To be able to buy vegetables from the likes of Crunchy Carrot in Dunbar or Phantassie in East Linton is my foodie heaven !It is probably more expensive to shop locally and, as you need to drive to dferent outlets, it does take longer.For hard-pressed working families, this is not always an option. A big supermarket shop, with selections of everything we need, is a necessary part of most householdsrsquo routine.This year, however, this never-ending choice and supply has clearly been disrupted. The perfect storm of pandemic, Brexit and bad weather has resulted in frequently empty shelves. Some products are unavailable.Prices are increasing. Recent reports of supermarkets recalling food ranges such as pre-prepared seafoods and cheese spreads because of risk of contamination indicate trouble in the system.The food journey to supermarket shelf is long. Ingredients are pulled together from multiple counties, even countries.The brilliant exercise in sourcing, logistics, and extending the le of ingredients has successfully given us the lsquowhat you want when you fancy itrsquo way of le we have become used to.But, having been forced to stop and reassess how we shop, eat and live, I suspect many families are keen to step back from this corporate sales pitch and rediscover the local delights on our doorstep.Steady queues at the doors of local food shops, increased numbers of local food delivery services and fish vans bringing an ever-increasing selection of fish from the pier to our kitchen sink is, to my mind, a positive outcome of a dreadful situation.Milk daily on the doorstep. Lucarsquos ice cream straight to the door.Whatrsquos not to like

title: tranent-shopkeepers-licence-sell-alcohol-held-six-months
story: Manish Kumar, who runs the Day-Today store, Tranent, appeared before East Lothian Licensing Board todayto ask for a personal licence to sell alcohol in the shop.Mr Kumar, who was described as the tenant of the shop, was asked to bring his application to the board after a previous hearing heard he had lodged it with Edinburghs Licensing Board as he lived in the city.But at a virtual meeting, the board ruled against granting the licence - instead ordering a six-month continuation of his application.The board heard that there was a possible pending court appearance involving Mr Kumar in relation to the alleged sale of alcohol to an underage male last October.Members of the board were told that no date for any court appearance had yet been scheduled and it was unclear whether a case would be going ahead.Board members took a -minute recess to discuss Mr Kumars application privately before ruling against issuing a licence.Councillor Fiona Dugdale, board convenor, said: "We are not happy to granttoday and would like to continue this for six months."

title: east-lothian-coastal-car-park-charging-sites-proposed
story: There are also proposals to extendparking charges to include two currently exempt car parks - at Back Sands and Levenhall Links, Musselburgh - and introduce overflow car parks at popular sites.East Lothian Council has launched a Land Management Review after a year in which record numbers of tourists descended on beauty spots.Among proposals being put forward are the creation of a new park exclusively for motorhomes at Barns Ness, near Dunbar, and a complete ban on overnight stays at coastal car parks.The consultation alsosuggestsa clampdown on campers by insisting only wild camping is allowed in coastal areas and defines wild campers as those who camp as part of a pedestrian or cycled journey, with equipment they can carry on them and in groups of four or less.The proposals come after an unprecedented number of visitors were seen in East Lothian during the pandemic last year with numbers estimated at million -  per cent more than in a normal year.A report lodged in the councils members library service describes a "motorhome invasion" in the summer with parking bays taken up.And it said July  was the busiest day in  years, according to East Lothians countryside rangers service.Coastal car parks overflowed with people parking illegally on access roads and wild camping incidents regularly saw groups of  tents gathered at any given site.The report said it was only face to face engagement with visitors by countryside rangers which helped the county avoid many of the dirty camping issues other Scottish beauty spots experienced but there were still issues with indiscriminate toileting and litter as well as fires causing damage to woodlands.Between June and August, , tents and motorhomes were recorded in the coastal car parks.RECAP: Patrols carried out after human waste left by campersThe report said: "The number of tents at both Yellowcraig and Tyninghame was particularly high and the most affected compared to other coastal sites, with one weekend recording tents at Tyninghame and  tents at Yellowcraig."Associated issues were fire damage to the SSSI grassland and dune habitats, irresponsible toileting, tree damage bythose scavenging for wood and generally camping out with the guidance with the Scottish Outdoor Access Code, to the inconvenience of other users or detriment of their experience with coastal sites."New camping information signage was installed although high levels of camping and fire sites persisted."The proposed changes to car parking rules would mean motorhomes would be unable to use any coastal car parks overnight and would be directed to the new park.The report revealed: "The council is in talks with Tarmac for Barns Ness to be a potential site specically designated for motorhomes." In relation to existing coastal car park provision, it is proposed to ban overnight parking, and control through a twilight parking enforcement service in the evenings and overnight."In this way, motorhome and campers can be directed to purpose-built accommodation. This will ensure that the coastal car parks which have been established as a resource will enable locals and visitors to enjoy the coast as opposed to being motorhome sites."A ban of overnight parking will effectively close the car parks for vehicle use and prohibit any vehicle from staying overnight "The proposed changes would also see an increased stretch of coastal road where parking is banned.No waiting restrictions are proposed for the B between Dean Road and Seton Sands Caravan Park and on the south side from Dean Road to Lyars Road, Longniddry.The public consultation went online today ateastlothianconsultations policy-partnerships land-management-rules

title: find-information-google-stores
story: The information includes your age, gender, profession and interests based on what Google has managed to find out about you from how you use its services.When you use Google products including the search engine and over services such as Gmail, the company collects data to personalise ads specically for each user in an effort to make them more successful.This information is available for anybody to see as long as you are logged into a Google account.How to find out what Google assumes about youIn response to a TikTok trend asking users what obscure facts they know because of their job, digital marketer and TikTok user @tiktoktrishkabob caused a huge stir on the video .She said: ldquoSo, Irsquom a digital marketer, and I donrsquot think anybody realises just how invasive Google is.ldquoAndyoursquove ever thought, ldquohuh, this is a weird ad for me to be seeing therersquos actually a website that you can go to, to see all of the assumptions Google has made about you based on your previous searches.ldquoSo, as long as yoursquore logged into a device thatrsquos logged into your Google account, typeadssettings.google into the search bar.ldquoAnd here, yoursquoll be able to see every assumption Google has made about you, and why you see the ads that you see.Kabob then goes through her own assumptions that Google has about her, stating that it has her age range, gender identity and parental status correct.Kabob says: ldquoIf you have ever Googled it, itrsquos somewhere in here.ldquoYou can edit specic factors, like Irsquom not even quite sure what microblogging is, and you can also turn off ad personalisation altogether. Hooray Big Brother.Kabob explains that you can turn off ads for anything that you see in your list. All you need to do is click it and yoursquoll have the option to turn it off.You can also turn off ad personalisation all together - the option is available at the top of the web page.ldquoIrsquom offendedThe viral video caused quite astir as this was information a lot of people were completely unaware of.The video currently has over two million likes and nearly , comments where users have shared their thoughts and feelings upon discovering what Google thinks about them.One user wrote: ldquoIrsquom offended that it estimated me being + - Irsquom !Another commented: ldquoHer: lsquoThis is super invasive and dangerous.rsquo Me: lsquoHaha, personality test gorsquoldquoGoogle said Irsquom single, middle aged, alcoholic and a cat lady. Irsquom  and allergic to cats, said another.Another user joked: ldquoIrsquom most offended that it thinks I like country music.

title: aldi-confirm-haddington-gateside-store-open-second-half-year
story: The supermarket giant has confirmed it plans to open several new stores in Scotland during , which will see the number of stores across the country reach .The new East Lothian store will be based at Gateside Commerce Park on the townrsquos western edge and will replace its existing store off Whittingehame Drive, which will close.Aldi also plans to create a further  jobs, including  roles in its new stores, in a boost to local communities throughout the country.Richard Holloway, regional managing director for Scotland, said: ldquoDuring an unprecedented year, our Aldi colleagues and thousands of suppliers rose to the challenge of feeding the nation with tremendous skill and courage.ldquoAs we look forward to , our commitment to investment and expansion in Scotland continues, and we are excited be to opening a further four Aldi stores during the year, and of course reaching our signicant th store milestone.ldquoWhile our focus very much remains in bricks and mortar shopping, the launch of our Click  Collect service in Scotland is perhaps one of our most signicant initiatives yet, expanding our existing eCommerce business to bring our full range of groceries online for the first time.

title: soup-kitchen-van-serving-help-people-musselburgh-area
story: Run by hospitality food service provider BaxterStoreyrsquos Chef Shack, and based outside Musselburgh East Community Learning Centre on Haddington Road, it provides free hot soup to iniduals and families from the Musselburgh area.The soup kitchen is open on Tuesdays and Thursdays, am to pm.Meanwhile, Musselburgh Area Partnership is funding initiatives to support people in the community, working with East Lothian Councilrsquos Connected Communities service.Pamela Martin, community development worker, said: ldquoWith lockdown in the county, we aim to provide additional support to iniduals and families.She explained that, through a call-and-collect system, people in the Musselburgh, Wallyford and Whitecraig communities could collect a four-person recipe bag with fresh ingredients to cook a healthy, nutritional meal.It was hoped this would enable families and iniduals to try out new foods and develop new skills and cooking techniques thanks to a weekly recipe.There is a discretionary charge of pound per bag, with one allocated to each household.A food pantry ndash a free, emergency and confidential service ndash is also operated on a call-and-collect basis by phoning   . title: windygoul-wombles-helping-clean-area
story: During lockdown and because of the restrictions in place, people have been staying closer to home and taking more opportunities to explore their locality,, something recognised by the grouprsquos founder, Alison Brown.When out and about with husband Craig and son Ethan last year, she noticed how one area in particular was covered in litter.She said: ldquoWhen the kids were out and about more I saw how bad the park behind Windygoul Primary School was and decided that I had to get a bag and tidy it up.ldquoIrsquom a person who doesnrsquot complain and just gets on with it but I thought that I better do something, and do it for other people, too.ldquoWe are living in a world where people are buying takeaway stuff more and spending more time outside.ldquoAbout  per cent of people are really responsible but there is that five per cent who continue to litter, and rubbish can also be blown into the sea.Alison, who lives on Lawson Way but was born in Northern Ireland, set up a Facebook group called Windygoul Wombles, and then held her first socially distanced event at the end of November.The page now has more than  members of all ages, with about - people attending each event.She also contacted and took inspiration from the Musselburgh street clean group.Ward councillor Gordon Mackett has been a big supporter of the Tranent group, allowing them to borrow litter pickers and a large dustpan and brush for clear up broken glass, and have access to pink bin bags. When placed next to a bin, the pink bags indicate to council staff that someone has taken part in a litter pick and the rubbish needs disposed.Due to the current pandemic, all those who attend an event are asked to remain socially distanced and or with their household group, wear gloves, and wear clothing suitable for the weather on the day.All the pickers and shared equipment used are cleaned thoroughly using antibacterial spray prior to each use.While the group started near Windygoul Primary School, which also provided the group with litter pickers, Alison decided to start covering other parts of the town.She hopes that, when restrictions allow educational activities and socialising among members, the group will be able to grow and take part in more litter-picking events.And some members have been taking matters into their own hands and picking up litter in their own time.Alison said: ldquoLots of people have been chatting to us when we have been out on litter picks and most of the comments we have received have been positive. People are really enjoying it.ldquoAnd thanks to the litter picks, people are spending a lot of time outdoors and socialising, while still staying safe of course.Thanks to their efforts, Alison is already beginning to see a dference.She added: ldquoHopefully people will start taking more pride in their local area again. I care about where I live and others should too. Some parts of East Lothian are very pretty.For more information, visit facebook groups windygoulwombles

title: making-rights-real-set-bring-human-rights-groups
story: Clare MacGillivray, previously a Scotland committee member with the Equality and Human Rights Commission, is now interim CEO of the new group, Making Rights Real.Clare, who won an International Association for Community Development global community development ambassador award last year, spent  working on a scoping study for the new charity.She said: ldquoIrsquove been working in human rights and community development for about six years, so when I left my last job I went to the [grant maker] Baring Foundation, in England, and said that we needed resources to scope out a new organisation in Scotland, which would support communities to use the power of human rights.Making Rights Real came out of a project run by the Scottish Human Rights Commission, which supported residents in Leith to use a human rights-based approach to access pound. million of council investment into housing improvements.Clare said: ldquoWersquove had brilliant support from a whole range of organisations in a Scottish advisory group, like the University of Glasgow, the Scottish Human Rights Commission, PPR [an organisation in Belfast that has been doing such work for  years] and others.ldquoAt the end of the scoping study, we set up Making Rights Real.ldquoWe got funding from the Corra Foundation, Joseph Rowntree Charitable Trust and the Baring Foundation to kickstart the work in Scotland.The new charity, based in Edinburgh, will now liaise with grassroots organisations and charities to enable them to work in a ldquohuman rights-based way and to hold authorities to account for human rights issues or failures.Clare said: ldquoA lot of those will be in relation to things like poverty, housing, access to education or, for trans people, access to healthcare.ldquoThere are loads and loads of human rights issues which have been compounded by Covid.ldquoThis work is about empowerment of people itrsquos around providing people with the capacity to hold authorities to account.A community conversation held in March last year, before the Covid lockdown, as part of Making Rights Realrsquos scoping study, saw about  people from statutory organisations, and students at Ross High School and the Scottish Childrenrsquos Parliament, gather for a meeting in Farsquoside, which was attended by Anastasia Crickley, former chairwoman of the UN committee on the elimination of racial discrimination.Clare, who lives in Tranent with her husband and three children, aged ,  and , added: ldquoWe were talking about what are the main human rights issues here in East Lothian and whether there was interest in taking forward a human rights-based approach.ldquoOn the back of that there was a bit of interest but, obviously, because of Covid thatrsquos put things on the backburner.ldquoBut those are some of the conversations Irsquoll be picking up now that Irsquom in post.And Clare emphasised the impact of Covid on human rights issues, ldquoespecially in relation to economic, social and cultural rights.She added: ldquoPoverty, the right to food, the right to adequate housing, homelessness, the right to digital inclusion ndash wersquove seen children who are not able to access online learning. How has that been responded to  How do people in social care access the right to healthcare ldquoA spotlight is now being shone on those issues, which means we have an incredible opportunity to build forward better ndash I donrsquot like saying lsquobuild back betterrsquo because what we had before was rubbish.ldquoIf wersquove got this pot of money for public services, how do we make sure that the rights of the most marginalised are put at the centre See twitter Rights_Real for more information.

title: covid-scotland-vaccine-passport
story: Jason Leitch, the countrys national clinical director, said the passports are an "interesting concept".But what are the passports, and how would they work in Scotland A vaccine passport is an internationally recognised travel pass which would prove whether or not people have had a Covid vaccine.It could,implemented, allow people to prove their status and potentially travel abroad.It is being pushed forward by former prime minister Tony Blair, who told Boris Johnson thatBritain should use itspresidency of the G to launch theldquointernational Covid Pass.It is far too early to say, however Mr Blair says he believes the passport scheme should consist of a single, standardised digital system. He says it should be capable of tracking and verying an iniduals vaccine status across the world.It could, according to Blair, involve not only how many vaccinations someone has had , but also any test results they may have had in the past.It is hoped that the data would be transferred using a QR code, which would be scanned by participating countries at borders and ports.In evidence to the Scottish Parliamentrsquos Covid- Committee on Thursday, Professor Leitch said coronavirus is likely to be present in some sort of ldquoendemic form for years to come.When he was asked about vaccine passports, hesaid: ldquoI agree it is an interesting concept, the WHOhave begun to look at it.He stressed the latest scientic evidence suggests vaccination is not a ldquobinary state, but there is precedent for travel restrictions based on vaccination ndash including yellow fever certicates.Prof Leitch said: ldquoI think we will probably move towards that. I havenrsquot seen the exact details of what Mr Blairrsquos think tank have said but I imagine itrsquos relatively sensible, itrsquos about doing it globally rather than just an inidual region of the world.Zurab Pololikashvili, the UN World Tourism Organisationrsquos secretary-general, last week told the Global Tourism Crisis Committee in Madrid: ldquoVaccines must be part of a wider, coordinated approach that includes certicates and passes for safe cross-border travel.The leaders of Spain, Italy, Greece, Cyprus and Malta have called for the introduction of certicates which designatea traveller has been vaccinated or not.On Monday, Australiarsquos education minister, Alan Tudge, said planned ldquodigital vaccine certicates would allow international students toto study in the country without the need for them to hotel quarantine.The head of the UKrsquos data privacy watchdog has told MPs she can see the benefit of Covid- immunity passports, but warned they came with privacy concerns.Information commissioner Elizabeth Denham was asked by MPs on the Digital, Culture, Media and Sportsub-committee on Online Harms and Disinformation about the possible use of special passports to allow those who had been vaccinated to move more freely.She said any such scheme would face substantial questions over its necessity and concerns over the sharing of health data, but warned of creating a ldquotwo-tier system where people who have received a vaccine have more freedoms than those who have not.

title: uk-close-normal-summer-according-expert
story: Dr Mike Tildesley, a member of Sage subgroup the Scientic Pandemic Influenza Group on Modelling , said scientists believed vaccines would block transmission of coronavirus but it was not yet known by how much.Speaking on BBC Radio rsquos Today programme, he said: ldquoIf we think optimistically,we follow the trajectory of the rollout of the vaccinehellip then hopefully we can be easing out of these controls that wersquove got in place sometime in March.ldquoBut I think even with that optimistic situation, it needs to be done relatively gradually.ldquoThe danger is of course as we do start to unwind controls then we offset the gains that we get from vaccination, so we need to be very careful.ldquoButthe vaccine rollout continues at high levels, and we do find that actually these vaccines are very good at blocking transmission as well as preventing severe infection, then wersquore in a good position.ldquoHopefully by the summer we can get back to something pretty close to what we have seen before the pandemic was normal.Dr Tildesley said the UK did ldquoneed to have these vaccines being pretty good at blocking transmission.He added: ldquoWe will start to gain much more information about that in the next month as we follow people who have been vaccinated and see what their ability is to pass on the virus should they get infected.ldquoItrsquos fairly early days yet.Askedvaccines needed to% block transmission, he said: ldquoI think probably not quite close to %, but I thinkwe have somewhere in the region of say  to %, then probably wersquore in a good place.He said vaccines were not % protective and some people would not have the vaccine.ldquoAs we ease the controls you get more mixing, and evena lot of the vulnerable population are protected then they have more risk, those that are not protected have more risk, he said.ldquoSo thatrsquos why a gradual easing of restrictions, combined with uptake of vaccine, is really whatrsquos needed.On Sunday, Health Secretary Matt Hancock said he was hopeful of a ldquofree great British summer.He said: ldquoIn six months we will be in the middle of, I hope, a happy and free great British summer.ldquoI have a high degree of confidence that by then the vast majority of adults will have been vaccinated.

title: council-pressured-abandon-plans-cull-pigeons-dunbar-bridge
story: Plans were revealed last month for a potential cull of the birds before netting would be put in place under the rail bridge on the townrsquos Spott Road to stop the animals from roosting title: british-armed-forces-veterans-honoured-uk-wide-project-mark-60-years-since-end-national-service
story: former servicemen, including men who served in Egypt, Jordan, Singapore and Iraq, are involved in a National Lottery-funded project called National Service Remembered.It has been  years since National Service ended in the UK and the campaign, run by the not-for-profit organisation Same but Dferent, captures an important period of the countryrsquos cultural history through the eyes of the men who served. Ceridwen Hughes, photographer and founder of Same but Dferent, has combined striking portraits, video interviews and written narratives to bring alive conscriptsrsquo experiences in one powerful exhibition.Michael Wilkinson, , who lives in Chester and served at Hednesford during his National Service, is one of the British Armed Forces veterans included in the project.And Michael believes the campaign, powered by the National Lottery Heritage Fund, provides a valuable insight into a unique period of Britainrsquos past.Michael, who was first conscripted in , said: ldquoWorking with the team from Same but Dferent on this project has been a totally positive experience.ldquoIt has brought back memories of happenings I have not thought about for many years.ldquoThis project has already influenced me. I look back on it as being a very positive experience.ldquoParticularly so as National Service ceased in the distant past. Congratulations on National Service Remembered ndash you have all done a wonderful job.Ceridwen, whose organisation Same but Dferent use the arts for positive social change and to highlight inequalities and bring communities closer together, added: ldquoTo spend time with these men was a real joy, and we hope this exhibition will inspire children and adults to speak to this older generation about their experiences. ldquoWe are really grateful to the players of the National Lottery who funded this project along with the Armed Forces Covenant Fund.High-profile stars were far from exempt from conducting National Service, with Brian Blessed, Michael Caine and Anthony Hopkins among some of the household names to serve.And television veteran Johnny Ball, who served in the RAF during the s, is supporting the Lottery-funded National Service Remembered campaign after describing his time serving as lsquothe making of himrsquo at the end of last year.National Lottery players raise pound million every week for good causes and play a critical role in supporting people, projects and communities during these challenging times.North Wales resident Elwyn Davies and Oswestryrsquos Ken Grain are two further veterans involved in the National Service Remembered campaign.Elwyn, , who served in Egypt and was stationed at Caterham in Surrey, helped guard equipment that had been sold off by the British Army at the end of the Suez Crisis.And his inspirational story is now being showcased with the help of the National Lottery Heritage Fund, which uses money raised by The National Lottery to inspire, lead and resource the UKrsquos heritage.The Fund creates positive and lasting change for people and communities and Elwyn says National Service Remembered is preserving his priceless memories.Elwyn, who was first conscripted in  and lives with we Margaret, , said: ldquoI would think that unless our stories were documented, the whole experience of National Service would be lost for ever.ldquoIt was, after all, something which affected thousands of young men at that time and was a big part of growing up.Ceridwen Hughes, photographer and founder of Same but Dferent, has combined striking portraits, video interviews and written narratives to bring alive conscriptsrsquo experiences in one powerful exhibitionKen, , lives in Oswestry and was posted at Singapore with the RAF as a Radio Direction Operator during the s.He met Princess Marina, Duchess of Kent, during her official visit and went on to work as a teacher when his time during the Forces came to an end.Ken was first conscripted in  after growing up in East Ham and said: ldquoIts been fascinating going back into my National Service le and remembering.ldquoIts important to remember it because a lot of people felt that it was a wasted opportunity but it was the best thing for young people.ldquoI think the project is a very good way of letting people know what happened during National Service. I was one of the lucky ones and it helped me with my future le. Same but Dferent would love to hear from anyone who wants to share their experiences of National Service - particularly anyone who was conscripted and has connections with Dorset. To contact the team or to view the exhibition, which will be touring the UK later in the year, please visit www.national-service

title: holywell-resident-davies-one-18-british-armed-forces-veterans-involved-innovative-national-service-remembered-project
story: Elwyn Davies, , who served in Egypt and was stationed at Caterham in Surrey, is one of  former servicemen included in a National Lottery-funded project called National Service Remembered.It has been  years since National Service ended in the UK and the campaign, run by the not-for-profit organisation Same but Dferent, captures an important period of the countryrsquos cultural history through the eyes of the men who served.Ceridwen Hughes, photographer and founder of Mold-based Same but Dferent, has combined striking portraits, video interviews and written narratives to bring alive conscriptsrsquo experiences in one powerful exhibition.Elwyn helped guard equipment that had been sold off by the British Army at the end of the Suez Crisis and believes the project, powered by the National Lottery Heritage Fund, provides a priceless insight into a unique period of Britainrsquos past.Elwyn, who was first conscripted in , said: ldquoI would think that unless our stories were documented, the whole experience of National Service would be lost for ever.ldquoIt was, after all, something which affected thousands of young men at that time and was a big part of growing up.ldquoI was a boy from a typical Welsh nonconformist background and hadnrsquot seen very much, I suppose.ldquoI was a little bit worried about going but afterwards, of course, it did me the world of good.Ceridwen added: ldquoTo spend time with these men was a real joy, and we hope this exhibition will inspire children and adults to speak to this older generation about their experiences.ldquoWe are really grateful to the players of the National Lottery who funded this project along with the Armed Forces Covenant Fund.High-profile stars were far from exempt from conducting National Service, with Brian Blessed, Michael Caine and Anthony Hopkins among some of the household names to serve.And television veteran Johnny Ball, who served in the RAF during the s, is supporting the Lottery-funded National Service Remembered campaign after describing his time serving as lsquothe making of himrsquo at the end of last year.National Lottery players raise pound million every week for good causes and play a critical role in supporting people, projects and communities during these challenging times.Fellow North Wales residents Eric Keen, Peter Hannen and John Hughes are also involved in the project, run by Same but Dferent, who use the arts for positive social change and to highlight inequalities and bring communities closer together.John Cresswell, who lived in Mold and died aged  last year, is also one of the British Armed Forces veterans whose experiences are being captured by the campaign.Elwyn grew up in Conwy before receiving his National Service call-up papers shortly after his th birthday.Elwyn was conscripted in  and is now married to Margaret, , and has two children and four grandchildrenHe set straight off to Egypt to undertake his gruelling battle training, served during the Suez Crisis before later retiring as a superintendent in North Wales Police.Elwynrsquos inspirational story is now being showcased with the help of the National Lottery Heritage Fund, which uses money raised by The National Lottery to inspire, lead and resource the UKrsquos heritage.The Fund creates positive and lasting change for people and communities and Elwyn hopes the next generation can learn from the lessons of yesteryear.Elwyn, who is married to Margaret, , and has two children and four grandchildren, added: ldquoI donrsquot think youngsters of today would put up with what we had to put up with.ldquoItrsquos doubtful I would think, but it was no question with us ndash you had to do it.ldquoIt was National Service, it was compulsory and that was it. We were in a dferent position to what they are now.The exhibition will be touring the UK later in the year and is available to see online at www.national-service

title: list-glasgow-shops-administration-lockdown

title: tv-five-minutes-mel-giedroyc
story: Cringeworthy confessions make for great television. However, when those revelations come directly from the mouths of renowned celebrities, its safe to say our interest has been piqued.Hosted by presenter and comedian Mel Giedroyc alongside her co-host and fellow comedian Lou Sanders, new Dave series Unforgivable does just that.Uncovering a range of stories - from the relatively mild through to the downright shocking, the show relieves celebrities of their long suppressed secrets without the need to set foot inside a church confessional.Described by Giedroyc as "a gleeful celebration of the outrageous", the series features a plethora of celebrity guests from across the world of entertainment, including the likes of Graham Norton, Jenner Saunders and Gemma Collins."I thought Come on, Im , this show is the best fun Ive had in ages, its time to let rip," says the Children In Need and former Bake Off presenter.Ahead of the first episode, we chat to Giedroyc to discover more about the show.How does the show work "We have three celebrity guests on every show and the aim of the game is that the person who can make themselves most unforgivable, wins the show."The scoring system is really quite complicated. It involves minus points. The lower the score, the better youve done. And you will achieve that by spilling the worst things about yourself. So that, in a nutshell, is what it is: show us what a horrendous person you are."There must be some memorable stories "Weve got everything from eating pets to scandalous goings-on in the bath. There are a fair amount of poo stories. There are childhood stories which are always brilliant and often quite charming because when youre a child you dont have quite the same sort of moral compass or sensibilities that you have as you get older."Any standout guests "Weve got Jenner Saunders on, who I absolutely adore shes hilarious. And it was so good to hear stories from her because she can actually be a shy person and she doesnt do that many shows like this."Graham Norton was absolutely wonderful. I love the way that he doesnt shy away from telling stories about himself... Gemma Collins was superb too - such a great storyteller with amazing timing."What is it that sets this show apart "You get to see some comedians that maybe we havent seen enough of yet. Some brilliant comics of the future, and I was all for that. Its really important and it gives the show completely dferent energy. It gives the show a bit of spice."And there are audience confessions too "The public confessions are more left-field, surreal and madder than you could ever make up. Its always the way, isnt it, that the stuff from real le is always the most outrageous."I hope the show taps into that in a very celebratory way because I think the show is a celebration its not trying to make anyone actually look really bad. Its just gleeful rather than condemning anybody."It must have been fun working with Lou Sanders "I adore her. I love her as a stand-up, and I love that shes so dferent from me. Sue [Perkins] calls me The Onion because there are so many layers to get through before I will actually say what Im properly thinking or feeling. Whereas someone like Lou, its all out there. She talks openly about everything. I blooming well admire that.""I call her the Keeper of the Filth. Shes my co-host and essentially the PA of the show: she holds the knowledge, she holds the book. shes the keeper of the filth. Shes like a filthy Richard Osman to my Alexander Armstrong."And you make some confessions yourself, dont you "Yes. God, I cant remember what. Did I say anything terrible  I did make a confession about working in catering on a friends short film. Everyone was working for free: the actors, the crew. Sue [Perkins] and I did it together and wed been slaving away, making food and snacks and drinks to keep everybody happy. There was this actress - I cant actually remember her name, she came to nothing! - and she had the audacity to come up and complain about something. And I thought, right buddy, youve complained to the wrong person because Im in charge of the food. So I snotted into her pasta and presented it to her."I felt really bad though because she came up at the end of the afternoon and said it was really delicious! But, you know, Ive been a waitress so many times in my le, and Ive worked behind bars. That sounds like I worked in prison. I dont mean behind bars like that. I mean bars as in pubs. Ive done so much of that in my le and I had such a short fuse with rude customers or people that were badly behaved. Never, ever treat a waitress badly. Youll end up with snot...or worse..in your food."Did Coronavirus play havoc with filming "Back in March  we were supposed to record and then the first lockdown was called literally on the day I was looking at costumes and going through scripts, and the guests were due to come the next day. So we were all sent home. Gutting."Then we managed to do it in October just before the next lockdown which was so lucky. We got in under the wire. And we were allowed a small audience. I think it was all beyond our wildest dreams, and wed all been locked up for so many months."Unforgivable launches on Dave on Tuesday.

title: food-feeling-off-kilter-might-need-think-yin-yang-plate
story: Food: Feeling off kilter  You might need to think about the yin and yang on your plateAsian Green by Ching-He Huang Her husband, Jamie Cho, started Huang on a "journey of self discovery", the -year-old chef and presenter says. explains. Within a month of trying it himself, Cho noticed improvements in his asthma, eczema and psoriasis.Of course, everyones body is dferent and may react dferently - its worth checking with a medical professionalyoure considering big diet changes, especiallyyou have existing health conditions - but for them, Huang says it was "quite a revelation".It encouraged her to experiment with plant-based foods, which initially felt at odds with her background. "Being a Chinese chef, we experiment, and being a Chinese food connoisseur youve got to try everything," she confesses.However, Huang did find plant-based eating aligned well with the Chinese philosophies shed been brought up on by her family in Southern Taiwan."Ive always believed in you are what you eat, [and] a balanced diet," she explains. "I grew up with my parents and my grandparents, and they eat seasonally."Think about yin and yang balancing hot and cooling foods depending on your body, a little bit like the Indian Ayurvedic principle of eating. If youre tired and stressed, your bodys very yang -youre always cold and shivery, then your bodys too yin, youre having too many yang and fiery foods."So how do you balance this yin and yang  Firstly, Huang says: "You literally just need to listen to your gut" - then youll be able to properly judge what your body needs. She remembers her grandmother saying"you eat too many vegetables, you need to have ginger because vegetables are yin and ginger is very yang - its fiery, so it balances your body. On a vegan diet, you need to have more garlic, ginger, chillies - more yang dishes," she explains. "Mostly, yang ingredients are from meat."How you cook your meals also plays a part. "Steaming is more yin and stir-frying is more yang," says Huang. "Overall, were trying to create the perfect balance. I think its really hard in the modern day to try and create this balance - to even understand it - but I think food is a conduit to that."We could be bombarded with all this technology and science, but you actually have to listen to our instincts."For Huang, it made sense to adopt a plant-based diet, saying it "aligns with who I am" - and the results make it worth it. Asked how she feels, she says: "Much healthier and lighter, I just have more energy - but obviously everyone should do whats right for them".The chef doesnt just think about the personal reasons for going plant-based, but the bigger picture as well. She says: "If we look at ourselves as an entity, then look at ourselves in a greater picture, in a way it is a reflection of what weve done to this planet - the way we pollute the planet and the way we over-consume."Everything is about balance, sowere out of balance, then were going to be ill. The same thingwe over-pollute the planet, its not going to create the best environment for us."Her recipes are democratic, she says. "Not all of us are from the same background, but we all love food and we want it to be a simple process. If you cook something and it works and you feel happy and satisfied about it, then youre more likely to cook again."Once people cook, its a way to express love, because youre taking care of yourself. And once you learn how to cook and youre confident, then you know how to cook for somebody ."For Huang, this is the ultimate way to show you care, and " you choose to cook compassionately, then youre looking after the greater and youre extending your love to everything ".Huang might look at things very philosophically but she does so with a light touch - and without any judgement. She just wants to encourage people to "try it for yourself". If youre thinking about a vegan diet, Huang recommends doing so with a group of friends, "so youre not alone".She says simply: "Whether its for animals, or your health, or you just want to try something new, I think people should celebrate more veg."Let this plant-based cheesecake transport you to a tropical island.Not convinced vegan desserts can be luxurious Why not try Ching-He Huangs recipe for creamy mango and cashew cheesecake...Mango and cashew vegan cheesecake recipeIngredients:For the biscuit base:g fruity vegan oat biscuitstbsp mixed nut butterFor the cashew cheese layer:g cashews, soaked in water for  minutes then drained and rinsedml coconut milkg plain coconut yogurttbsp coconut creamtbsp golden syrupJuice of  limePinch of sea saltFor the fresh mango compote: mangos, peeled, stoned and diced into .cm cubestbsp golden syrupTo garnish:Zest and juice of  limeMethod:. To make the biscuit base, crush the biscuits in a food processor. Add the nut butter and process until well combined. Transfer the mixture to a bowl and set aside. Clean the food processor.. Place all the cashew cheese layer ingredients in the food processor and blend until smooth.. Line the base of a cm round glass cheesecake dish with the biscuit and nut butter mixture and press into place. Pour over the blended cashew cheese mixture. Cover and let it set in the refrigerator for  minutes.. Meanwhile, make the mango compote. Place the mango and golden syrup in a shallow frying pan over a medium heat. Stir gently to combine. Cook for two to three minutes until the mango has softened and the mixture is slightly sticky. Take off the heat and let cool for  minutes. To assemble, remove the cheesecake from the refrigerator and top with the cooled mango compote. Just before serving, garnish with the lime zest and juice. Enjoy!Asian Green: Everyday Plant-based Recipes Inspired By The East by Ching-He Huang, photography by Tamin Jones, is published by Kyle Books on February , priced pound.

title: recipe-simple-tasty-lentil-ham-soup
story: Ingredients, serves  + x ham hockg red lentilsfrac stick celery x onion dice x swedeFreshly ground pepperMethodPlace the ham hock in a deep pan, cover with water and bring to the boil. Turn down to a gentle simmer and continue to cook for around . hours or until the meat is falling from the bone.When the ham hock is cool, pick the meat from the bone keeping the stock from the ham.Add the lentils followed by the vegetables to a pan and add the ham stock.Bring back to the boil then turn to a simmer, cooking the lentils until soft.
